awd_titl_txt: P2C2:  Testing Whether Internal Dynamics is the Pacemaker of the Indian Summer Monsoon Variability on Decadal to Centennial Timescales
awd_abstract_narration:
The researcher aims to develop millennial-length (1,000-2,000), absolute dated, and high resolution (inter-annual to sub-decadal) oxygen isotope records of speleothems from caves located in western, southern, and northern India.   The goal of the research is to provide Indian summer monsoon (ISM) histories at the regional level that are analogous to the instrumental records from distinct macro-meteorological units.

The investigator notes that seasonal precipitation associated with the ISM tends to be dominated by two time scales of variability: (1) interannual variations which are attributed to slowly evolving external boundary conditions (e.g., tropical Pacific SST), and (2) intraseasonal oscillations (e.g., 10-20 and 30-60 day active-break cycles) which are driven by internal dynamics that modulate convection and propagation of embedded synoptic systems. There is no conclusive evidence to indicate which one of these two forcings is the dominant pacemaker of ISM variability on interannual and longer timescales.

The premise of the research is that existing instrumentally-calibrated and inter-annually resolved oxygen isotope speleothem records from central and northeast India supports the hypothesis that the internal forcing, which manifests in the form of chaotic rainfall variability during the monsoon season, is the dominant pacemaker of ISM variability.  

On the basis of the current data, the research will test the working hypothesis that, on decadal and centennial timescale, systematic changes in the frequency characteristics of active-break cycles serve as a medium by which ISM responds to changes in the external boundary forcing.

The broader impacts involve a better understanding of Indian Monsoon dynamics and the support of undergraduates in the research effort from currently under-represented groups.

The Indian summer monsoon (ISM) exerts profound influence on humanity, yet the dynamical processes that govern its complex spatiotemporal variability are far from well understood. This project was aimed at building a network of instrumentally calibrated and inter-annually resolved oxygen isotope records of stalagmites that were recovered from caves throughout the Indian subcontinent. Our objective was to assess the full spectrum of ISM behavior in both spatial and temporal domains and to determine its potential end-member scenarios. Manifested in our proxy records is an evolving view of monsoon dynamics - one that exhibits types of low frequency and high amplitude variability that have not been observed during the short instrumental period including its repeated tendency to lock into extended (years to decades long) extreme dry and wet phases.  Building upon our previous work, this research has further contribute to a fuller characterization of monsoon behavior in both space and time The salient aspects of our research are as follows:

Our speleothem-based precipitation provide novel insight into the role of internal dynamics in generating ISM variability on decadal to centennial timescales. Our speleothem records provide clear evidence for ISM’s repeated tendency to lock into extended (lasting years to decades) dry and wet extremes (with a generally opposite response between central and northeast India). We hypothesize that through sustained changes in the frequency characteristics of the active-break cycle, ISM responds to large-scale changes in the external boundary condition. Importantly, we find that transitions between the ‘active-dominated’ and ‘break-dominated’ states can occur rapidly (<10 years), which imply presence of threshold behaviors in ISM - an observation that may prove significant in considering how ISM will respond to a warming global climate

 

We provide a classic example of threshold type behavior in ISM by documenting ISM variability across the 4.2 ka event. Using a high-resolution speleothem stable isotope record from northeast India, we document a dramatic climatic event ~4000 years ago. The precise dating of this record provides a very signi?cant advance with respect to age control and sample resolution of terrestrial climate change over South Asia during this period. The event was characterized by a massive decline is ISM rainfall. While evidence of a causal relationship between climate and the reorganization of the Indus Valley and Old Kingdom Nile civilizations is beyond the scope of our study, the tight age constraints of the record that we provide show with a high degree of certainty that much of the documented deurbanization of the Indus Valley at 3.9 kyr B.P. occurred after multiple decades of a shift in the monsoon’s character but before the monsoon returned to its previous mid-Holocene state.
